title: 110_hr7178
content: The "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" allows for waiver of sovereign immunity under the 11th Amendment for enforcement of USERRA. The amendment to Section 4323 of title 38, United States Code, allows actions against a State to be brought in federal or state courts. It also includes a waiver of State Sovereign Immunity for individuals related to federal financial assistance programs. The amendment to Section 4323 of title 38, United States Code expands the rights and benefits for employees in federal financial assistance programs. It applies to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred, and to all actions filed after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. UNENFORCEABILITY OF AGREEMENTS TO ARBITRATE DISPUTES ARISING UNDER USERRA. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, prohibits the enforcement of arbitration agreements between employers and employees for disputes under this chapter, except in cases where parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises or in valid collective bargaining agreements. The validity and enforcement of this section will be determined by Federal law. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, prohibits the enforcement of arbitration agreements between employers and employees for disputes under this chapter, except in cases where parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises or in valid collective bargaining agreements. The validity or enforceability of an agreement to arbitrate shall be determined by a court, rather than the arbitrator, irrespective of whether the party challenging arbitration does so specifically or in conjunction with other terms of the agreement. This section applies to all contracts and agreements between an employer and an employee, regardless of when they were established. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, prohibits the enforcement of arbitration agreements for disputes under this chapter, except in specific cases. The provisions of section 4327 apply to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, before or after the enactment of this Act, and to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. Additionally, enhanced remedies for the enforcement of USERRA are included in the Act. Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include remedies for State or private employers who violate the provisions of this chapter, making them liable for damages such as wages, salary, benefits, or other compensation denied or lost by the affected person. State or private employers who violate the provisions of this chapter are liable for damages including wages, salary, benefits, or other compensation denied or lost by the affected person, along with interest and liquidated damages. In cases where employers violate the provisions of this chapter, the court may award liquidated damages not exceeding 100 percent of the compensation awarded. Additionally, for violations by employers with 25 or more employees done with malice or reckless indifference, punitive damages must be paid to the affected person. The court may also require the employer to comply with the provisions of this chapter and provide the right to a jury trial. The right to a jury trial is granted to individuals who initiate legal action under this chapter. If a Federal executive agency or the Office of Personnel Management violates employment provisions, the Board can order compliance and compensation for lost wages or monetary losses. The Board can award compensation for monetary losses, interest on the amount, and liquidated damages in cases of violations of employment provisions by Federal executive agencies or the Office of Personnel Management. If the violation was in good faith, the Board may choose not to award liquidated damages or limit it to 100 percent of the compensation or damages awarded. The amendments made by this section apply to any violation of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, before or after the enactment of this Act. This includes all actions filed under chapter 43 that begin after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 amends provisions of USERRA to require the award of attorney fees in actions to enforce rights. The amendments apply to violations before or after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6 clarifies the definition of "successor in interest." The term 'successor in interest' for determining purposes is amended to include a multifactor test, regardless of the form of succession. The successor's lack of notice of a potential claim at the time of succession is not considered in the test. The multifactor test for determining 'successor in interest' now includes merger, acquisition, or other forms of succession. The amendment applies to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred, and to all pending actions or complaints under the same chapter. SEC. 7 clarifies that USERRA has no statute of limitations, applying to all violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 8 prohibits wage discrimination against members of the armed forces. SEC. 8 clarifies that USERRA prohibits wage discrimination against members of the armed forces by amending Section 4303(2) of title 38, United States Code. The amendment applies to all violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred. Section 4323(e) of title 38, United States Code is amended to require courts to use certain criteria when determining whether to issue an injunction or restraining order in cases of employer denial of reemployment. This includes considering such denial as irreparable harm and balancing the hardships between parties. The amendments made by subsection (a) require courts to consider specific criteria when deciding on injunctions for employer denial of reemployment. This includes weighing the harm to the employee against the harm to the employer, with a presumption that reinstating the employee is in the public interest. These amendments apply to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, both before and after the enactment of this Act.
